speaker: Martin
text: Ah, I still say when some guy grabs your parking space, you don't just sit there, you say something.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, when a man has no front teeth and stitches on his nose, I think it's safe to assume he's sensitive to criticism.

speaker: Martin
text: [_picking up a box_]  What's this?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh must be one of those inspirational tapes that Daphne's always listening to.  [_Daphne comes in from her room._]  Oh, my God, 'Here, Have a Rainbow', by Dr. Honey Snow.  Daphne, how can you listen to this stuff ?  It's absolute dribble.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, for someone who writes dribble, she's awfully popular.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really, fancy that.  She tells everyone that they're perfectly wonderful and that nothing wrong is ever their fault.  What do you know, they like it.

speaker: Daphne
text: There's a lot more to it than that.  You should try reading one of her books.  [_Doorbell rings, Frasier goes to get it._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I have.  Believe me, after one page, I was yearning for the worldly cynicism of Barney the Dinosaur.  [_He opens the door to reveal Niles._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles, to what do we owe this pleasure?

speaker: Niles
text: Brace yourselves kids, it's raffle time!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God .

speaker: Martin
text: Not again

speaker: Niles
text: Fraid so.  [_notices tape_]  Oh ye gods, who's been plumbing the shallows of Dr. Honey Snow?

speaker: Daphne
text: I have.

speaker: Niles
text: Insightful, isn't she?  [_Daphne is not amused._]  Anyway, tickets are only ten dollars, it all goes to support Maris' little opera group.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God, what's the grand prize this year?

speaker: Niles
text: Their lead soprano, Mrs. Fitzgibbons, will come to your home and perform 'The Ride of the Valkyres'.  We've sold eight hundred tickets, so the risk is pretty minimal.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.

speaker: Niles
text: In return, let me offer you a hot stock tip:  VectorComp Software.  Wendel assures me they can't miss.

speaker: Martin
text: Who's Wendel?

speaker: Niles
text: My new broker.  Every stock he's put me onto has paid off. The man is positively clairvoyant.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, I've got a bit tucked away.  Maybe I ought to take a little chance with your Wendel.

speaker: Niles
text: I should warn you, it's not a sure thing.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, nothing in life is a sure thing, but Dr. Snow has a little saying:  Nothing ventured, nothing gained.

speaker: Frasier
text: She better copyright that before some unscrupulous hack steals it.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll go in for five hundred.  That's a lot for me, but I don't know; I have a little feeling I'm in for a bit of luck.  All right, I better get ready.  I'm off the the Book Nook.  Dr. Snow is signing copies of her new best seller.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, wait a minute.  You're going out?  What about my whirlpool therepy?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, right, I forgot.  Maybe you could go to the book signing for me, Dr. Crane.  It's right around the corner from the station.

speaker: Frasier
text: I would sooner attend a ho-down.

speaker: Niles
text: I would gladly go, but I've got my compulsive spending seminar, and I'm hoping to unload the rest of these raffle tickets.

speaker: Martin
text: What's the big deal?

speaker: Frasier
text: I have my reputation to think of.

speaker: Niles
text: What's the big deal?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, if it will make you all happy to see me humiliate myself.

speaker: Martin
text: I always get a kick out of it.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thanks ever so.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_noticing Eddie rolling around on the floor_]  Oh, look everyone!  Eddie has found his inner puppy!  [_Fade out._] **ARE THERE ANY MORE LIKE YOU AT THE INSTITUTE?**  [_Fade in.  Roz and Frasier enter._]

speaker: Frasier
text: I promise this'll just take a minute.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I hope so, I barely got an hour for lunch.  Oh, God, not another one of those Honey Snow books.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading the cover_]  'Don't Change, You're Perfect'

speaker: Roz
text: Can you believe people go for this junk?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's unbelievable.  Here, get her autograph for me, will ya?  [_Roz gives him a 'What?!' look_]  She's sitting right behind those people over there.  Just go get it signed and then we'll get out of here,  go have a nice lunch at Le Cigare Volant.

speaker: Roz
text: Me?  Why don't you do it?

speaker: Frasier
text: I have my reputation to think of!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, what's the big deal?  [_off his glare_]  All right.  [_He picks up another copy and looks it over.  A woman comes up._]

speaker: Woman
text: Oh, it's wonderful isn't it?  I just love what she says about finding a moment each day to stop and give yourself a mental hug.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm giving myself one now.

speaker: Woman
text: Really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Welll actually it's more of a Heimlich manuever.  [_Roz comes back._]

speaker: Roz
text: Got it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good, good.  Let's buy it and get out of here.

speaker: Roz
text: Nope, nope, not so fast.  She wants to meet you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I don't want to meet the woman, let's just go.

speaker: Roz
text: Uh, Frasier, do you know what Honey Snow looks like?

speaker: Frasier
text: What difference could that make?  The woman stands for everything that I find totally...  [_Dr. Honey Snow walks up.  She is tall, blonde and buxom._]

speaker: Frasier
text: ...enchanting.

speaker: Honey
text: Hello.  I'm Dr. Honey Snow.

speaker: Frasier
text: And I'm...wait, don't tell me, Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Honey
text: Well, Dr. Crane let me shake your hand.  Oh, what am I saying?  Hug.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why not?  [_They hug._]

speaker: Honey
text: After all, a handshake is just a hug for fraidy cats.

speaker: Frasier
text: No fear here.

speaker: Honey
text: I am one of your biggest fans

speaker: Frasier
text: I've recently become one of yours.

speaker: Roz
text: You know, I think I'll just go get started on my appitizer.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes, you start without me.  All I really want is a little nibble.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, tell me.

speaker: Honey
text: You know, I really should get back to my signing, but I'd love to talk more.  There seems to be such a positive energy betwen us.  My publisher is giving me a dinner tonight at seven at Bianchi's.  Would you come as my guest?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'd love to

speaker: Honey
text: Well that's great.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well it was nice meeting you Dr. Snow.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, please, it's Honey.  [_She goes back to the signing._]

speaker: Frasier
text: It certainly is...  [_Fade out._] **YOU SCRATCH MY BOOK...**  [_Fade in.  Martin is watching a horse race on television.  Daphne opens the door for Niles._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Good evening, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Good evening Daphne, Dad.  Ooh, watching the sport of kings I see.  Which horse did you wager on?

speaker: Martin
text: Gerald's Dream, number eight.

speaker: Niles
text: Goodness, he seems to be taking a serene, almost Buddhist approach to the race.  [_Marin, disgusted, turns off the set._]

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps you should have invested in something more reliable. Like VectorComp Software.

speaker: Daphne
text: Our stock.  Did it go up a bit?

speaker: Niles
text: No, it went up a lot.  Thanks to a takeover bid, it gained forty percent overnight.  Wendel advised selling, so, voila, your original five hundred investment plus two hundred profit.  [_He gives her a check._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Two hundred?  Oh, Dr. Crane, I could kiss you!  [_She kisses him on the cheek and hugs him tightly.  Niles is stunned._]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's a nice little dividend.

speaker: Niles
text: [_sitting downon the arm of the couch_]  I'll say.

speaker: Daphne
text: You have to help me decide what to do with it.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you might want to consider letting Wendel reinvest it. That's what I'm doing.  It's called rolling it over.  [_Frasier comes in._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Then I'll do it.  Oh, this is so exciting.

speaker: Frasier
text: What's all this?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, your brother just gave me two hundred dollars, and now he's going to roll me over.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: Communications breakdown

speaker: Frasier
text: Good.

speaker: Niles
text: What are you all dressed for.  Hot date?

speaker: Frasier
text: As a matter of fact, yes.

speaker: Niles
text: With whom?

speaker: Martin
text: Dr. Honey Snow.

speaker: Niles
text: You're dating Dr. Honey Snow?  I thought you considered her a complete ninny.  What could you possibly see in this [_Martin hold up the dust jacket photo_] whoa-hoa mama!

speaker: Martin
text: One hell of a cute shrink, huh?  Not a man alive wouldn't let her analyze his dreams.

speaker: Frasier
text: Analyze them? She could star in them.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, yes, but what on Earth do you say to her when she wants to discuss her work?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I just simply skirt the issue.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course.  'Honey I think your books are just - oh look! The waiter's on fire!'  [_The doorbell rings, Frasier goes to get it._]

speaker: Frasier
text: You're just jealous.  But not half as jealous as you're about to be.  I suggest you get a coaster for your lower lip.  [_He opens the door, it is Honey._]

speaker: Honey
text: Hi, honey.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Honey. Allow me to make the introductions.  Daphne Moon, Honey Snow;  Honey Snow, Daphne Moon.  She's a big fan of yours.

speaker: Both
text: Hug!  [_they hug_]

speaker: Daphne
text: We've both got sort of unusual names.  Daphne Moon, Honey Snow.  Come to think of it, if you married my father, you're name would be Honey Moon.  [_Frasier, exasperated, sort of shoos her away._]

speaker: Frasier
text: My father, Martin Crane.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, hello.  Well it's easy to see where Frasier gets his good looks.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, get outta here.

speaker: Frasier
text: And, last but not least, my brother Niles.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, Dr. Niles Crane.  I read a wonderful article you wrote in the Journal of Psychiatric Medicine.  Let's see: 'Gestalt Therepy, Probing the Subconscious'.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  And I believe I read your quiz in Cosmo:  'Is Your Guy a Stud or a Dud?'

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps we should be going.

speaker: Honey
text: Well, actually, not yet.  I have something I want to give you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh?

speaker: Honey
text: [_handing him a box_]  It's a manuscript of my upcoming book.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Another one?  So soon?

speaker: Honey
text: I hope you like it Frasier.  Because if you do, I'd love for you to write the foreword.

speaker: Frasier
text: Me?

speaker: Niles
text: [_taking the manuscript_]  Who better?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually there's so many other people that would be more qualified to write for such an important work.

speaker: Honey
text: Well, if I didn't know better, I'd think you didn't want to do it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no, no, no, no.  It's a great honor.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll say.  The last book had an introduction by Mickey Rooney.

speaker: Martin
text: Wow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well there's no two ways about it, then.  I'm writing that foreword.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, that's great.

speaker: Daphne
text: Just think.  By next fall there'll be half a million copies in print with your name right on the cover.

speaker: Niles
text: I've got my Christmas shopping done!  [_Frasier gives him a dark look as he leaves with Honey.  Fade out._] _Act 2  Scene 1 - Frasier's Apartment_ **SHRINK RAP**  [_Frasier is typing on his laptop.  Niles is reading Honey's manuscript, laughing._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, will you please stop giggling?  It's very distracting.

speaker: Niles
text: I can't help it.  Have you read this?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm trying to recommend the book.  Reading it doesn't help. OK, here, how's this:  Many great volumes have been written about human behavior.  And I can honestly say, without fear of contradiction, that this book can stand on the shelf next to any of them.  [_off Niles' look_] No good, is it?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no but this is:  [_reading from the manuscript_]  You don't have to be a star to twinkle.  Frasier, I need a hug.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, will you please help me?  Honey asked me to write this foreword two weeks ago, she's got a deadline, she's been wondering where it is.

speaker: Niles
text: Time is a concept known only to one of God's creatures: man.  Just for today, be a sunflower.  [_points to a paragraph in the manuscript_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, give me that!  Nies you just don't understand what's at stake here.  I've never felt this way about a woman before. I'm out of control, her effect on me, it's, it's. there are no words to describe it, really, it's more like a sound... [_makes a growling noise_]  [_Martin comes in with Eddie._]

speaker: Martin
text: Talkin' about Honey again?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: Frankly, I find it laughable that you're even considering putting you name on five hundred thousand copies of this piffle.  Not even piffle.  It's piffle light.  [_Daphne comes in wearing a nice coat and carryin shopping bags._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, good, you're all here.  I want to show off me new coat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very nice Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, I've been spending like a drunken yuppie.  Oh, I'm afraid I went a bit over me budget.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, if it's cash flow you're concerned about, you should know I got a little call from Wendel today.

speaker: Martin
text: What, again?  What's that, four times in two weeks?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, the man's a wizard.  Daphne, your profit.  [_gives her a check_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Four hundred dollars?  Oh, Dr. Crane!  [_She kisses him._] And here's one for Wendel.  [_She kisses his other cheek._]

speaker: Niles
text: Did I mention Wendel has a secratary?  [_He puckers up._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, you!  [_Swats him on the stomach._]

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'd say this calls for a celebration.

speaker: Daphne
text: Tell you what, I'll take you all out for a nice dinner, my treat.  I'll just go and put on me new dress and we'll be off.  I want you to put on your new shirt with your brown courdroy slacks.  [_She heads to her room._]

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, if you're payin', I'm gonna wear elastic waist pants and no belt.  [_He heads to his room._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles, that broker of yours, he's a marvel!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, he's doing wonderful things for me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I'd say so.  I've been so impressed with his winning streak lately that I asked Daphne what her latest pick was, I invested a few hundred myself.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?  Well, congratulations.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  But there's just one thing, though, it's very hard to figure out.  Allthough I invested in the very same stock that Daphne did, mine declined and hers went up.  How do you explain that?

speaker: Niles
text: Obviously, one of us is lying, Frasier.  What are you up to? Frssier:  Fess up, Niles, this whole stock thing was a lie from the get go.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, that's not true.  The first stock really did pay off, but then the rest all tanked.  And what was I supposed to do?  Tell that poor, working class Venus I'd lost her life savings?  I had to pay her back and I threw in a little extra, and where's the harm in that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you are giving a woman money to obtain physical affection.  We are talking the world's oldest profession. Granted, this is sort of the Walt Disney version, but still.  It's wrong, and I insist you stop it.

speaker: Niles
text: No.  It's altruistic, it's noble, it's fun, and you can't make me stop.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_coming back out_]  Well, Dr. Crane, I want you to take this four hundred dollars back and buy whatever Wendel says.

speaker: Niles
text: Consider it done.  [_Martin comes out._]

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Niles, I've been thinking maybe I should get on that gravy train myself.  Tell Wendel I'm in for ten thousand.

speaker: Daphne
text: Good lord, ten thousand dollars, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well just think of the dinner I'll be able to buy when Niles brings me my profits.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what the hell, put me down for a couple of hundred. This guy's some kind of genie!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, he's a real treasure, isn't he?  I only hope those chest pains he was complaining about this morning turn out to be indigestion.

speaker: Daphne
text: So, shall we go then?  I've decided on Farmer Jack's Chicken, Chicken, Chicken.  I hear the chicken there is very good.

speaker: Martin
text: Are you comin'?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you two run along.  I'll take my car.  [_Daphne and Martin leave._]  Well, I hope you're happy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Snap out of it.  What you were doing was completely dishonest.

speaker: Niles
text: Said the pot to the kettle!

speaker: Frasier
text: What is that supposed to mean?

speaker: Niles
text: I think you know what it means.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't be ridicoulous!  Our two situations are completely different.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really?  How so?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for one thing, you've been misleading a woman for your own selfish gain.

speaker: Niles
text: And so are you!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm not finished.  She was also trusting you to tell the truth.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, and the difference would be?

speaker: Frasier
text: Your woman is English!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, you've lost this one.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know.  I know.  Just going to take a little while to climb down off of this particular high horse.

speaker: Niles
text: I think you know what you have to do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  I have to tell her I can't write the foreword.  Oh, Niles, and I have to say goodbye to the chance of ever sleeping with absolute perfection.  Oh, where oh, where will I ever have the chance again to gaze upon such extraordinary proud and supple breasts?

speaker: Niles
text: Not to worry brother, that's the manager's special at Farmer Jack's Chicken, Chicken, Chicken.  [_Fade out._] [_Fade in.  Honey and Frasier come in, Frasier waits at the door._]

speaker: Honey
text: That was a wonderful dinner, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well thank you for the fabulous table.  I think hugging the maitre d' really clinched it.

speaker: Honey
text: Would you care for a night cap?

speaker: Frasier
text: Sure.  [_He comes in._]

speaker: Honey
text: You know, you seemed really tense all evening.  But I have just the thing.  It's a sandlewood candle.  The scent is guaranteed to calm you down.

speaker: Frasier
text: You better fire up about ten of those.  You know, there's something I'd really like to talk to you about. It's about that foreword I've been trying to write for you.

speaker: Honey
text: Can we not talk about work tonight, Frasier?  I've been chained to my desk all day researching an article I'm doing on sexual intimacy.  I am up to here with 'The Joy of Sex', 'Karma Sutra', Masters and Johnson...

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Honey
text: I feel like I've been reading recipes all day, only there are no groceries in the house.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, your bag-boy has arrived.  [_They kiss._]  No, no, no, I really need to discuss this now.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, you.  You are such a workaholic.  I only hope you're this tireless about everything.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't think you'll have any complaints.  [_He starts to take his tie off._]  No, no, no, I've got to focus on the subject at hand.

speaker: Honey
text: Frasier, tonight I am the subject at hand.  [_They start to make out and fall to the couch._]

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, Honey, I can't do it!

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, that's all right, I have a candle for that too.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, I, I can't write the foreword.

speaker: Honey
text: Well, why not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I, I just didn't think it was a very good book.  I think the world of you and I wish you the greatest success, but I didn't think the book was good enough to put my name on it.  I guess I'l be going now.

speaker: Honey
text: I am so attracted to you right now.  Most men are so eager to have sex they'll say anything to a woman.  How great to meet a man who would risk rejection rather than be dishonest?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I, uh...have to be true to my inner voice.

speaker: Honey
text: You know, frankly I thought the book was weak myself.  I rushed it to meet a deadline.  I am so glad you respected me enough to be honest.  I think honesty is the greatest aphrodesiac of all.

speaker: Frasier
text: I hope you feel you can be just as honest to me.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, I do, I do.  Tell me everything.  I don't want us to hide anything.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought your chapter titles were clumsy and jejune.  Your turn.

speaker: Honey
text: You use way too much French in everyday conversation.  You go.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think that sandlewood stinks.

speaker: Honey
text: Oh, when you talk about wine, I wish I had a gun.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought your first three books were trite and saccharin. [_She freezes._]  It's your turn Honey.  Honey?

speaker: Honey
text: [_pulling away_]  I am immensely proud of my first three books.

speaker: Frasier
text: As well you should be.

speaker: Honey
text: You thought they were trite?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, I meant trite in its best sense.  As in the phrase 'trite and true'.

speaker: Honey
text: And what about saccharin?

speaker: Frasier
text: I love saccharin.  Use it every day.

speaker: Honey
text: Well, I'm glad you like saccharin, darling, because there's no way you're getting any honey.   Good night Frasier.  [_She gets up and holds the door open._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Honey, I'm sorry, I really am.  Couldn't we try one of your foregiveness excercises?

speaker: Honey
text: Good night, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hug?

speaker: Honey
text: You know a poet once said something about the world that I think applies to our relationship:  'It ends, not with a bang, but with a whimper.'  [_Frasier whimpers.  Fade out._]
